label.text: A river ecosystem in Asia supports two species of fish: a species of minnow and sweetfish.
The minnows eat algae that inhabit the centre of the river and aquatic insects that inhabit the edges of the river.
The minnows live in the river all year round. The sweetfish migrate to the sea for part of the year.
minnow [species not clear; in English is a generic term for many species of small freshwater fish - any equivalent for translation would do]

text.strong: ‌Population density in parts of the river when both fish species are present‌
‌Population density in parts of the river after sweetfish have migrated to the sea‌

label.text: The migration of many fish species is regulated by changes in day length.
The growth of many organisms, including algae, is often controlled by environmental temperature.
Many species time their migrations to arrive in at a location during the peak supply of food. For the sweetfish, this means arriving when algae are most abundant.
What would the consequence be for sweetfish if global warming results in an increase in the temperature of their river habitat?
The graphs to the right show that there is a change in the population density of minnows in the centre of the river after the sweetfish migrate to the sea.
Suggest a reason for this observation.
